list_page_teaser: I often get my friends to answer the questionnaire so I can learn more about them and draw their image.  View this gallery to see the resultant images, and learn about them as well.
description_html:
These are some images of my friends, from when I wrote the original version when I was in grad school.

I will be adding more friends to this page, as I gather their scores and get their ok to add them, so check back soon!

image_list.title: Jim Armstrong
image_list.subtitle_html: A Best Friend Forever
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Jim was one of my best friends for many years when I was growing up in Richmond, Virginia.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in Jim's spiritual portrait represents his passion.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.  Jim was one of the warmest, friendliest people I have ever met!
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in Jim's spiritual portrait represents his realism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.  In those days I would frequently vote for third parties (that ended in 2000), but Jim was more realistic and, to my knowledge anyway, always voted Democratic.
image_list.story_html:
When I lived in Richmond, Jim was one of my best friends. He was the center of a group of us and the only one I have seen to score 100% Extraverted on the Keirsey Temperament Sorter.

The portrait shows that Jim was a very warm, open person. And I regret to note that I say "was" because Jim passed away April 5th, 2002.

I know for a fact I am not alone in missing him very much, even after all these years!

image_list.title: Roy B. Scherer
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Roy Scherer is a friend I met through some of my Libertarian friends when I lived in Richmond, Virginia.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in Roy's spiritual portrait represents his pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in Roy's spiritual portrait represents his preference for making logical decisions.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.
image_list.story_html:
When I wrote the original version of the Groja © Program in college in Richmond, Virginia, I was very interested in Libertarianism. During that time I was able to get Roy B. Scherer to answer the questions in the Keirsey Temperament Sorter. Roy is still a Libertarian who continues to lobby in Richmond Virginia for gun rights and the legalization of marijuana.

Here is an image of his personality. One might think that marijuana legalization would be a passionate issue, but his portrait shows that, for him at least, it was largely a matter of logic.
